Ljubitelji gob, ali nabirate suho polževko?
Suha polževka raste jeseni, posamično ali v skupinah; je užitna goba, zamenjamo jo lahko s preostalimi večjimi polževkami, vse so užitne.
06 Nov 2019, 16:35 by Ana Ivanovič



Suha polževka je ena večjih polževk. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič



Klobuk je na temenu grbast in rahlo oranžen. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič



Goba je precej velika in čvrsta. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič



Lističi so široki in beli, bet pa rahlo rumenkast. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič



Lep pogled na polno košaro polževk, kar se ne zgodi pogosto. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič


Trenutno je poleg zapoznelih gobanov mogoče najti polževke, gobe, ki spadajo v družino Hygrphoraceae, ki jo je leta 1907 predlagal nizozemski mikolog Johannes Paulus Lotsy. Vključuje številne izredno lepe gobe, nekatere prav velike, druge majhne, lepljive in sluzaste, denimo bela polževka. So različnih barv, od oranžnih, rumenih in belih do temnih barv, nekatere barvo spremenijo šele v starosti. Zaradi tovrstnih sprememb jih je včasih težko ločiti in je treba iskati vzorce na različnih stopnjah razvoja. Včasih je treba katero gobo raziskati pod mikroskopom, saj je sicer ni mogoče zanesljivo določiti.
Goba je užitna, čeprav nekateri menijo, da ni posebno okusna.
Klobuk suhe polževke (Hyrophorus penarius) ima premera od 6 do 10 centimetrov; je mesnat, čvrst in trd, rob je kar dolgo spodvit. Kasneje se razširi, na sredini ostane grbica okraste barve. Površina je suha in gladka, v vlažnem vremenu je lahko rahlo lepljiva. Trosovnica je v obliki lističev, ki so beli do svetlo okrasti, debeli, široki in potekajo rahlo po betu navzdol. Bet je do 8 centimetrov visok, trd, čvrst, poln, bele barve in v dnišču nekoliko rumenkast. Mlad je rahlo lepljiv, kasneje je suh in ves drobno nakosmičen. Meso je belkaste barve, čvrsto in debelo, z vonjem po gobi in brez posebnega okusa.


Goba je precej velika in čvrsta. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič

Goba je užitna, ena najboljših med polževkami. Pripravlja se na vse mogoče načine, tudi pri kuhanju ostane precej čvrsta, kar nekateri zelo cenimo. Sicer pa se večine gob ne sme kuhati predolgo, saj lahko v tem primeru razpadejo. Ker poznam ljudi, ki so kuhali gobe uro in še več, sem zdaj toliko bolj zadovoljna, kadar poskusijo moj način priprave, z ne predolgim kuhanjem. Gobe namreč vsebujejo od 80 do 90 odstotkov vode in so zelo kmalu kuhane. Nekatere lahko uživamo celo surove, denimo užitne gobane, prav tako blagve, čeprav jih ne smemo nabirati, saj so zavarovane, a to nekaterih prav nič ne moti. Nekateri poznavalci omenjajo, da polževka ni preveč okusna, vendar to ne drži povsem, je namreč prav odlična, če jo pravilno pripravimo. Meni je najljubša ocvrta.


Lističi so široki in beli, bet pa rahlo rumenkast. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič

Suha polževka raste jeseni, pod listnatim drevjem, najraje ob bukvah in hrastih, posamezno, še raje skupinsko. Zamenjava je mogoča s preostalimi večjimi polževkami, na primer z gozdno polževko, pesniško polževko in še s katero. Vse so užitne, razlikujejo se večinoma po barvi in nekoliko po obliki. A če polževk ne poznamo prav dobro, je bolje, da jih ne nabiramo. Držimo se prvega in edinega pravila nabiranja gob: nabirajmo le tiste, ki jih dobro poznamo.


Lep pogled na polno košaro polževk, kar se ne zgodi pogosto. FOTO: Ana Ivanovič
text:
Mushroom lovers, do you get a dry snail?
Dry snail grows in the fall, individually or in groups; it is an edible mushroom, it can be replaced with the remaining larger snails, all edible.
06 Nov 2019, 15:35 by Ana Ivanovich



Dry snail is one of the larger snails. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich



The hat is bumpy and slightly orange at the top. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich



The sponge is quite large and firm. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich



The leaves are broad and white, the bet slightly yellowish. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich



A nice view of a full basket of snails, which doesn't happen often. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich


At the moment, in addition to the delayed mushrooms, snails, mushrooms belonging to the family Hygrphoraceae, proposed in 1907 by the Dutch mycologist Johannes Paulus Lotsy, can be found. It includes a number of extremely beautiful mushrooms, some just large, others small, sticky and slimy, such as white snail. They are in different colors, from orange, yellow and white to dark colors, some change only in age. Such changes can sometimes make them difficult to separate and patterns need to be sought at different stages of development. Sometimes a sponge has to be examined under a microscope as it cannot be determined reliably.
The mushroom is edible, although some consider it not particularly tasty.
The dry snail hat (Hyrophorus penarius) has a diameter of 6 to 10 centimeters; it is fleshy, firm and firm, the edge is long curved. Later it expands, in the middle there remains a coat of ornamental color. The surface is dry and smooth and can be slightly sticky in wet weather. The bridle is in the form of petals, which are white to lightly round, thick, broad and run slightly downwards. The bet is up to 8 inches tall, hard, firm, full, white in color and slightly yellowish at the bottom. The young is slightly sticky, later it is dry and all finely hairy. The meat is whitish in color, firm and thick, with a mushroom-like odor and no special taste.


The sponge is quite large and firm. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich

The mushroom is edible, one of the best among snails. It is prepared in all possible ways, even when cooked, it remains quite firm, which is greatly appreciated by some. Otherwise, most mushrooms should not be cooked for too long, as they may fall apart. Because I know people who have cooked mushrooms for an hour and more, I am now so much more satisfied when they try my method of cooking with not too long cooking. Mushrooms contain 80 to 90 percent water and are cooked very soon. Some can even be eaten raw, such as edible mushrooms, as well as goods, although they should not be harvested as they are secured, but this does not bother some. Some connoisseurs mention that the snail is not too tasty, but it does not quite hold, it is excellent if cooked properly. My favorite is fried.


The leaves are broad and white, the bet slightly yellowish. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich

Dry snail grows in autumn, under deciduous trees, preferring to beech and oak, individually, and even more to the group. Replacement is possible with the remaining larger snails, such as forest snail, dog snail and more. They are all edible, differing mostly in color and slightly in shape. But if the snails are not well known, it is better not to harvest them. Let’s stick to the first and only rule of mushroom picking: let’s pick only those we know well.


A nice view of a full basket of snails, which doesn't happen often. PHOTO: Ana Ivanovich
